title: Which NFL team's offense will average the most yards per game in the 2020 regular season?
preds: Unless something happens in the NFL which has never happened before (the first place team - Kansas City - gains next to no yards total offense and the next teams - Arizona, Green Bay, Buffalo, Tennessee - gain over 500 yards), the Kansas City is a shoe in for this title. It has never happened before and I do not anticipate it happening this week. Kansas City it is.

There is no change to the forecast this week. While mathematically, all teams are still alive, it would take close to 0 yards of offense from the Chiefs in order to not lead this category at the end of the season. After Week 15, they currently rank #1 with 427.9 yards of offense per game; the next closest team is Tennessee with 399.4, followed by Arizona with 399.2 (https://www.teamrankings.com/nfl/stat/yards-per-game).
This could mathematically be wrapped up after this week's slate of games.

No chance of anyone making up the difference in two games unless something unimaginable happens and KC gets nearly no yards in the next two games. They have about a 400 yard lead over the next team (5,990 to 5,591), with only two games to go. In order to catch up, the Titans would need two 627+ yard games while the Chiefs average 427, or the Chiefs would have to average <200 yards per game on the next two games while the Titans average their 399 yards. It seems very unlikely that this will be the case.
KC has a 1,014 yd lead over TEN with 2 games remaining.

Kansas City continues to lead the league by over 30 yards per game (429.2 to 2nd place Green Bay at 397.6). It appears they will continue to play their starters until they lock up the #1 seed and first round bye in the playoffs, which may not happen until Week 17 is completed.
Arizona is #4 at 389.5, Chargers at #8 at 383.0, and Seahawks at #6 with 387.5 yards per game. It appears unlikely, with only three games remaining, that any of these teams could catch the Chiefs, but as long as they are playing football, there is the slightest of chances they could.
Green Bay and Tennessee are the only two teams averaging above 390 yards per game not named Kansas City. It also appears unlikely either of these teams could dethrone Kansas City, but there is always a chance depending on rest for starters late in the season. However, the overall forecast is skewed heavily toward Kansas City and rightfully so.
Through Week 14.  KC put up 448 yds to GB's 410. They both face roughly the same level of defense in their last 3 games, and GB would need to make up 410 yards to overtake KC.  Not likely.
With a quarter back who can run, throw, run and throw, and a great offensive line to protect him. Unless injury sidelines him, he is the one to beat for a second year in a row.
4 games left in the 2020 regular season. KC leads Green Bay at 427.6 vs 396.6. Will update before the end of the season

The Chiefs continue to put up astronomical numbers on offense and lead the league in yards per game by over the next closest team (Green Bay) by over 30 yards (source: https://www.teamrankings.com/nfl/stat/yards-per-game). With only 4 regular season games left, it would take major performances by any team below Kansas City as well as a complete tank on offense by the Chiefs (and they will most likely be fighting to secure the #1 seed in the AFC up to / including week 17 due to sharing an 11-1 record with the Steelers and currently losing the tiebreak) to make up the difference on an averaged basis, regardless of opponent, location, weather conditions, etc.

Through 13 Weeks, the KCC average 427 yards per game, with the GB Packers, Rams, Vikings, and Titans trailing.  With 4 regular-season games remaining, this crown is the Chiefs' to lose.  The trailing teams will not be able to make up enough ground with the remaining games, especially since KCC have favorable matchups against Miami, Atlanta and the Chargers left on the schedule.

Adjusting again, there are only 4 games left, so it is unlikely that any team will be able to catch the Chiefs with such a big advantage. I wish I didn't let my hopes for my team (Seahawks) partially cloud my original forecasts, but hopefully I am in early enough to counter-balance.

Through Week 13. KC is still in the lead with 427.6 ypg - based on their opponents, they should end at 417.7ypg ARZ, LAC, and SEA fell out of the top 4 and it will be a tough hill to climb to catch KC (although LAC has faces the weakest defenses the rest of the season). GB is now in 2nd with 396.6ypg and projected to end the season at 392.2 ypg.  LAR, MIN, and TEN all moved ahead of the original 3 that dropped.  Leaving ARZ, LAC, and SEA at 1% and giving them each one more week. LAC should put a lot of yards on the board against ATL in Week 14 and SEA will likely do the same against NYJ. ARZ will face a stingy run defense with NYG. Both KC and GB face weaker defenses as well in MIA and DET respectively. However to pass KC, GB would need get 372 yards more than KC in the last 4 games of the season, which seems highly unlikely unless they can make up a big chunk of that in Week 14.
Updating after Sunday, still have three more games this week to finish the week out.

Using the same strategy as last time and updating with the past weeks data and decreasing the number of remaining weeks by 1, I get the chiefs winning 99% of the time. This makes sense given their massive lead in the YPG stat and their good form recently.
Based on current statistics and strength of remaining schedule in regards to defense rakings for yards/game.

Kansas City Chiefs have Relatively Easy difficulty Rating and a Better Offensive Record and a good season and a good Power Index
https://www.espn.in/nfl/fpi
http://powerrankingsguru.com/nfl/strength-of-schedule.php

KC would need to average roughly 360 per game over their last 5 games to drop to Arizona's level (assuming everyone else keeps their average). 360 is roughly average for the league.  For Arizona to get to KC's level, they'd have to average over 470 yards per game. Seems very likely that KC will finish as the leader.

Kansas City's offense has been heating up lately and Arizona's offense has come back down to earth. Exactly what I had mentioned would need to happen to the Cardinals offense and the Chiefs offense for this to change drastically has, and it has tipped the scales in favor of the Chiefs. Arizona still has a favorable schedule and conditions vice the Chiefs, but based on recent performance, the Chiefs offense looks unstoppable. With arguably the best QB in the league and other veteran stalwarts, they hold over a 22 yard per game average on the Cardinals at this point. As the denominator continues to get bigger, the odds that the Chiefs finish with the higher output increases.
The Chargers still have a punchers shot at maintaining their offensive pace, but the Bills exposed some flaws in their offensive game this past week. Green Bay has inserted themselves into the conversation, but tough conditions make it unlikely that they will continue with an extremely high output. Lastly, Seattle's offense is doing enough to win right now but not much more, especially with questionable play-calling by their HC and OC.

NFC teams are all playing against good defenses. Chiefs have to play every game to try to catch Pittsburgh for the bye. Their defense has been mediocre, so I expect even more reliance on the pass. Green Bay could blow out some teams and come into the equation.

After this week, it looks like the Chiefs are starting to run away with it. However, the Cardinals could catch up since they have an easier schedule. The Seahawks are still in it since they have potentially the easiest schedule out of the four teams mentioned. It looks like the Chargers will potentially lose to all of the other three teams on here.

Updated through Week 12. LAC still faces the weakest defenses the rest of the season - currently 397.8 ypg; expected outcome is 392.7
KC lit it up with 543 yds this week and 460 last week; they also face the weakest pass defense of all four temas here - at 425.8 ypg with an expected outcome of 413.3
ARZ only managed 298 against NE - at 403.7 and faces the toughest defenses of the four teams here down the stretch, expected finish at 390.3
SEA fell out of the top 5 with a 301 performance at PHI; at 391 expecting 381.7 GB snuck into 4th and we'll keep an eye on Rodgers down the stretch - will keep an eye on them to see if they warrant a deeper look going into Week 14.

After the chiefs offensive explosion, putting up 500+ yards this week, they now lead the NFL in ypg by about 20 a game over the cardinals and chargers. Using the same technique as I did last week, I get the following results: Chiefs: 89%
Cardinals: 7%
Chargers: 2%
Seahawks: 1%

The Kansas City Chiefs have proven to have a potent offense that can put up points against any team in any setting. The only chance the Seahawks and Cardinals have in over taking the Chiefs, is the fact that they are fighting for playoff seeding. I don't see any other team putting up more points than Kansas City this year.

Broad picture: I felt like the probably assigned to the two favorites is really high considering the small gap at the top. The Cardinals and chiefs are only 100 yards above the chargers and seahawks which is just one good or bad quarter for an offense.  I tried to solve this problem more computationally by computing the mean and variance of yards per games for each of the top 4 teams and then simulating 6the remaining 6 games using draws from a normal distribution based on that mean and variance. Then, I determine which team had the most yards for the year based on that. My results from 10,000 iterations:  Cardinals: 42.9% lead the league in ypg
Chiefs: 41.6%
Chargers: 8.2%
Seahawks 7.3%  This is much higher odds for the seahawks and chargers than given by the crowd. And given I have the seahawks having the most yards at the end of the season 7.3% of the time, I think it's possible for the Rams, Packers, and Vikings to lead the league by the end of the year.  Inside factors:  1. Dominant teams might rest players for the last game of the year, which seems pretty likely for at least the chiefs
2. Schedule the rest of the way: 
Chiefs face a few good defenses (saints, bucs, dolphins)
Cardinals face a few good defenses (patriots, rams x2, 49ers)
Seahawks have an easier schedule
Chargers is somewhere in the middle  Given that, I think I'll go pretty close to the simulation, but giving a few points to another team given the chance of the packers, rams, or vikings.

There was a massive adjustment the previous game, as suddenly the Seattle defense showed up (for what seems like the first time all season) and shut down the Arizona offense. This was the exact type of swing needed that I mentioned in my previous comment, albeit one that was from the least expected of defenses. Likewise, the Chiefs torched the decent Raiders defense, putting the teams at 414.3 and 414.1 yards per game respectively. The Chargers and Seahawks are still at 400 yards per game and as the season winds down and more games are played, there would need to be bigger shifts in the yardage accumulation to adjust those averages due to denominator increases. 
I still believe that quality of defenses and weather will play an issue as the season rolls on, favoring the Cardinals offense. However, I am adjusting my forecast significantly to give the Chiefs a decent shot while drastically lowering the Cardinals forecast.

Updated through Week 11. ARZ only mustered 314 yards against SEA who allows on average 434.9 ypg while SEA managed 347 yds against an ARZ defense that allows 367.7 ypg. LAC managed 376 yds against a NYJ defense that allows 400 ypg. KC put 460 yds on the board against LV who allows 385.8 ypg. All 4 teams have 6 remaining games (Team -  Opponent avg yards allowed per game): ARZ - 326.5 (they play the stingy LAR twice who are only allowing 291.9 ypg and SF who is allowing 315.9 ypg)
KC - 348.4 (play TAM 310.5 ypg and NO 302.2 ypg; but have ATL who is allowing 406.8 ypg)
LAC - 370.9 (also play ATL at 406.8 ypg and LV 385.8 ypg)
SEA - 337.5 (plays LAR 291.9 ypg, SF 315.9 ypg; but do get NYJ allowing 400.0 ypg) As of now ARZ and KC are with .2 ypg of each other and LAC plays, on average, the weakest defenses the rest of the season. KC plays weaker pass defense teams than ARZ does and Mahomes should put up some good numbers in the air.
Adjusting the other team to a lower probability.

Cards have a 5 yard lead with 414.3. I looked at each team's schedule and their opponents based on yards per game allowed. There weren't major problems for any team except the Seahawks who end the season by playing the 7th best, 5th best, and 2nd best in that category, Based off of my NFL following I would probably favor the Chiefs, but the Cardinals already have the lead, 1 less game, and a worse defense allowing them to have more possessions and more chance for yardage. I will give the cards the edge and keep an eye on the Chiefs and Chargers from week to week.
Based on schedules and home versus away games.
I think KC will have many passing games because the opponents have strong offenses (e.g. MIA, TB, NO, LV)

Assuming all remaining games are player with no significant injuries. ARZ leads currently at 425.4 ypg; faces the toughest defense of the four named teams here, including playing LAR twice who sits in second on defense allowing only 296.4 ypg. Overall the remaining schedule yields an aggregate 344.8 ypg. This will bring the 425.4 ypg total down to the a most likely value around 408 ypg. KC has 409 ypg and faces a schedule with an aggregate defensive total of 354 ypg. I project the most likely average for them to finish around 397 ypg LAC has 403.7 ypg and faces a schedule with an aggregate defensive total of 376 ypg. Most likely outcome should be about 398 ypg. Expect to see a lot of yards on the board in Week 11 against NYJ and a few weeks later versus ATL to keep them in the mix here. SEA has 405.9 ypg and faces a schedule with an aggregate defensive total of 344 ypg. Most likely outcome should be about 392 ypg. There are a number of teams worth following at this point (currently in the 395 - 397 ypg range) - ATL, DAL, GB, LAR. In week 11, SEA plays ARZ and you can expect to see a lot of yards on both sides with the edge to ARZ.

The Cardinals currently lead the league in team offense with 425.4 yards per game. This is significantly above the second place team (Kansas City) who averages 409.0 yards per game. In fact, over the last three games, the Cardinals have averaged over 470 yards per game, which is 60 higher than the next best team over that span (LA Rams). (Source: https://www.teamrankings.com/nfl/stat/yards-per-game)
The Cardinals play three more times at home, but also play three games on the road in what could be prohibitive conditions for offenses (Seattle, New England, New York). The Cardinals offense would have to get completely shut down on multiple occasions while another offense would have to light it up for the averages to swing in the favor of another team. The LA Chargers (averaging 20 yards less per game than the Cardinals) are fourth in the league, but run a pass heavy offense which racks of yards due to a) playing from behind and b) garbage time. Their schedule on the way home is a mix of good conditions, poor defenses, and with nothing to play for regarding playoffs and a coach perhaps coaching for his job, they can play loose, despite a rookie quarterback (who is playing much better than expected).
KC is in the playoff hunt, but have a challenging schedule coming home and a location where unpredictable weather mean that conduciveness to yardage gains becomes a factor. Seattle has a favorable schedule on the homestretch, but also a challenging location in the Pacific northwest. However, the difference between KC and Seattle is that Seattle's defense is one of the worst in the league and, in order to remain competitive, they must put points on the board and fire on all cylinders offensively to win games.
The "Another Team" category is led by the Falcons and Packers, but they would need significant offensive performances over the last 6 games to close the gap and it is not looking as likely as the teams mentioned above.
However, the gap between the Cardinals and the other NFL teams is rather large for a team to catch them. A major injury could change the assessment, but at this point in the season, the Cardinals are well on their way to claiming this crown.
